68.heading: Ballala.
68.title: "Raja Bhoja : a Patron of the Arts and Literature"
68.author: script, Kamala Chandrakant ; illustrations, G
68.appears_in: R. Naik ; editor, Anant Pai. p. 1-32 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 596 (1976, 2010 printing).
notes: Begins: "Raja Bhoja was the son of King Sindhula of Dhara, in Madhya Pradesh. He was born when Sindhula was very old."

Summary from back cover: "Amidst the many wars he fought, Raja Bhoja (11th century A.D.), the ruler of Malwa, always found time to listen to the poetry of the gifted. Ballala, a poet in his court, has immortalised his patron in his work Bhoja Prabandha which is a romantic tale, written in Sanskrit, partly in verse and partly in prose. Ballala was interested not so much in history as in heroics. In his attempt to magnify Bhoja as a patron of the arts and letters, Ballala has ignored historical facts. The poets, Kalidasa and Bana, who he said adorned Bhoja's court, actually lived much before Bhoja's times."

But something is different about Kurara-she is acting very oddly. Sometimes she seems wholesome, pure, and innocent, and at other times she is extremely forward and unabashed. Kouhei soon learns that Kurara has multiple personalities-and decides to help her keep her secret from their classmates. But Kouhei finds himself struggling between helping Kurara as a friend and trying to win her heart, which is a challenge, since she has many!

"Yaya's high school friends haven't been very nice. They call her "Yaya the cry-ya! Yaya the misfi-ya!" but no matter how badly they act, Yaya is just too naive and trusting to believe the worst of them. Hard rocking, butt-kicking Nana is just the girl to grab hold of Yaya's timid demeanor and turn it upside down. Nana exposes Yaya's "friends" as slimeballs, doles out punishment, and does it all with style. Can there be anything that terminally shy Yaya and hyperconfident Nana have in common? Well, for one thing, they're the same person."

Summary (from OCLC): His name is Deucalion, a tattooed man of mysterious origin, a sleight-of-reality artist who's traveled the centuries with a secret worse than death. He arrives as a serial killer stalks the streets, a killer who carefully selects his victims for the humanity that is missing in himself. Detective Carson O'Connor is cool, cynical, and every bit as tough as she looks. Her partner Michael Maddison would back her up all the way to Hell itself, and that just may be where this case ends up. For the no-nonsense O'Connor is suddenly talking about an ages-old conspiracy, a near immortal race of beings, and killers that are more, and less, than human. Soon it will be clear that as crazy as she sounds, the truth is even more ominous. For their quarry isn't merely a homicidal maniac, but his deranged maker.

There, Syaoran meets his "Kudan": a fierce wolf-spirit whose fiery power mirrors Syaoran's personal strength. But with foes like a pop idol who sings words of pain, Syaoran's hunt for feathers is no child's game! Even if he finds the feathers, will Sakura ever wake up from her magical sleep? 252.title: Forbidden Dance. v. 2
252.author: written and illustrated by Hinako Ashihara.
notes: Summary: "Aya sneaks out of the all-important National Ballet Competition to look for her best friend Nachan. It's a race against the clock as Aya searches for her distraught friend while trying to get back in time for her own performance. But when Nachan threatens suicide, will Aya be able to tear herself away in time? The world of dance can make or break you, and dancers must find within themselves the will and the resolve to overcome any setback in order to make their dreams come true."

266.heading: Ballet Troupes.
266.title: Forbidden Dance. v. 1
266.author: written and illustrated by Hinako Ashihara.
notes: Summary: "When a young girl named Aya loses her confidence to dance, she fears she'll never set foot on the stage again. But then she sees Akira and the COOL ballet troupe perform, and everything changes. Akira inspires her to pursue her dream and dance again. Soon, her primary goal is to join the COOL ballet troupe. She's never wanted anything more in her life! There's only one problem: COOL is an all-male dance troupe, and Aya is 100% female. But so what if she's missing a Y chromosome? Aya's got spunk, skill and passion, and in the end she hopes that her undying determination will help her beat the odds."

285.title: Ballad for a Coffin
notes: Ballad for a Coffin / Jean-Michel Charlier, Jean "Moebius" Giraud, co-creators. -- New York : Epic Comics, 1989. -- 62 p. : col. ill. ; 28 cm. -- (Blueberry ; 2) -- (Epic Graphic Novel) -- Originally published in 1974 as: Ballade pour un Cercueil. -- Second in the "Confederate Gold" series. -- Genre: Western. -- Call no.: PN6747.C44B2813 1989

Summary: In the ghost town of Tacoma, just as the outlaws finish digging up the grave Trevor has indicated, Trevor makes a break for it. Finlay shoots Trevor's horse and Trevor's arm is broken in the fall, but he makes it to where he has hidden a rifle and holds the outlaws off from a balcony. A squatter named Lazarito kills him for his horse, boots and guns, and rides away. Lopez and his men find the hideout, and while they are searching for Blueberry, Pearl, and co., these latter sneak out and steal Lopez's horses and ride towards Tacoma. On the way they meet the peon who killed Trevor, and Pearl recognizes her husband 's boots. Pearl kills him and finds a message Trevor left in one of his boots: the name on the grave to which he has moved the gold. Mike gives Trevor a decent burial, with words about honor, and slaps Pearl to the ground when she speaks disrespectfully. The Yankees find the second coffin in the church as indicated by the note in the boot, but it's very heavy so they leave Pearl behind and ride to get a wagon. Finlay has been watching and moves in to question Pearl, and she stands them off from the locked bell tower. Meanwhile Lopez and his men find their horses and the dead peon, and decide to head for Tacoma. Watching outside Chihuahua, Blueberry and friends finally see a suitable wagon owned by a patent medicine dealer who is being run out of town. They save him from a lynching and promise him $1,000 for his wagon. Back at Tacoma, Lopez and his men arrive and run the Confederates off, then start trying to get at Pearl themselves. She makes a deal with them that if they hide in ambush she'll deliver Blueberry into their hands. Blueberry arrives in the quack's wagon and manages to get through the ambush before the soldiers recognize him. The coffin is loaded into the wagon and the bottles and kegs of snake oil are converted into fire bombs and smoke bombs. Next morning Lopez has brought a cannon, and fires it at the church. Blueberry sets off the various bombs and escapes in the wagon. What remains of Lopez's forces, including the men chasing Kimball and Finlay, begins racing to catch the wagon before it crosses the border. At the Herrera Depot Blueberry switches the coffin to a stagecoach with fresh horses and takes off with the empty wagon to mislead the soldiers. After blowing up the wagon and further diminishing Lopez's forces, Blueberry leads them to the stagecoach which is just crossing a bridge. As planned, the bridge gives way and Lopez with several other men and horses are lowered violently into the Rio Conchos. At the next stagecoach depot, Vigo and his men are waiting in ambush. Pearl surprises Vigo and they are able to grab Vigo as a hostage and load the stagecoach on a ferry. Finlay and Kimball are waiting on the other side, so they cut the rope and let the ferry drift downstream. The Rio Conchos empties into the Rio Grande, so if they make it they've reached the border. It's a tough trip. The body of Lopez floats by. The current is high, but they make it to Texas. They sink the ferry and Blueberry heads for Salinas to contact General McPherson. Finlay and Kimball catch him and make him change clothes with Kimball. Then Donnogan the bounty hunter takes Blueberry from them. Blueberry overpowers Donnogan and asks him to cable McPherson. Meanwhile Kimball, using Mike's clothes as a disguise, finds the stagecoach. As they labor to open the coffin, Vigo laughs. Vigo has known all along there was no gold, only scrap metal. The gold has been used to finance Juarez's revolution against the Emperor Maximilian, according to Vigo. Vigo's mission has been to keep people from finding out the gold was gone, because "Washington" thinks the gold belongs to the U.S. government. The Mexican government is afraid the U.S. will use the missing gold as a pretext to grab more Mexican territory. Vigo tells McPherson that Blueberry pocketed the gold, and Blueberry goes to prison for 30 years. Pearl starts a dance hall in Salinas. Kimball and Finlay kill each other.

This summary is from European Comics in English Translation (Jefferson, NC : McFarland & Company, 2002). Used with permission.
